There are 3 major axes of the shoulder:

1. Transverse Axis: Allows movements of flexion and extension in the *sagittal plane* @jonesProjectFoundations2025
1. Antero-posterior axis: Allows movements in the *frontal plane* @jonesProjectFoundations2025
1. Vertical axis: runs through the intersection of the sagittal and frontal planes and controls the movements of flexion and extension @jonesProjectFoundations2025.

# Joints

The Shoulder complex is made up of 3 joints and 1 pseudo joint:

1. [SCJ]({{< var ref-sternoclavicular-joint.path >}}) provides *gross* movement of the clavicle @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017.
1. The [ACJ]({{< var ref-acromioclavicular-joint.path >}}) provides fine motor control of the clavicle @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017.
1. The [glenohumeral joint](#glenohumeral-joint)
1. The [scapulothoracic (pseudo) joint](#scapulothoraic-joint)

![Left Acromioclavicular and Glenohumeral joints (anterior view) @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Syndesmology/image326 gray1918 The left shoulder and acromioclavicular joints, and the proper ligaments of the scapula.gif){#fig-gray1918-image326}

## Acromioclavicular joint {#acromioclavicular-joint}

The acromioclavicular joint (ACJ) is an articulation 

The ACJ has poor stability since the joint surfaces do not interlock making it prone to dislocations @jonesProjectFoundations2025.

The acromion aspect of the joint is slightly convex and faces supero-antero-medially @jonesProjectFoundations2025.
The clavicular aspect is flat or slightly convex and faces infero-postero-laterally 

Since these two facets can be flat or even both convex, they have poor joint congruity and in 30% of cases, an intra-articular fibrocartilage meniscus is present to improve congruency @jonesProjectFoundations2025.


This joint's stability is augmented by 2 extra-articular ligaments for stability: [trapezoid lig.]({{< var ref-trapezoid-ligament.path >}}) and [conoid lig.]({{< var ref-conoid-ligament.path >}}) @jonesProjectFoundations2025.


[Read more about the Acromioclavicular joint (ACJ) here]({{< var ref-acromioclavicular-joint.path >}})

# Ligaments


"(GH Ligs) Together with the coracohumeral ligament, these ligaments form a Z-pattern on the anterior aspect of the shoulder (Fig. 16-6).3 In the midrange of rotation, the G-H ligaments are relatively lax" @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020

# Flexion & Extension

Flexion and extension are movements of the shoulder that occur in the *sagittal plane* about a *transverse axis* @jonesProjectFoundations2025.

| Movement | GHJ | Scapulohumeral | Total |
|-|-|-|-|
| Extension | | | 45-50&deg; |
| Flexion | 120&deg; | 60&deg; | 180&deg; |
: Normal ROM for shoulder flexion and extension @jonesProjectFoundations2025 {.striped}

# Abduction & Adduction {#abduction-adduction}

Abduction and adduction of the shoulder refers to frontal/coronal plane movement occurring about an antero-posterior axis.

Normal abduction is 180&deg; @jonesProjectFoundations2025.

During abduction, the should complex made up of the [GHJ](#glenohumeral-joint), [ACJ](#acromioclavicular-joint) and [STJ](#scapulothoraic-joint) work together in 3 distinct phases to complete the whole range of motion.

1. 0-60&deg; abduction takes place *only* at the glenohumeral joint @jonesProjectFoundations2025.
1. 60-180&deg; is a combination of glenohumeral joint *and* the scapulothoracic joint @jonesProjectFoundations2025.

## Abduction




There are 4 abductor muscles that form a force coupling of shoulder abduction @jonesProjectFoundations2025.

- Glenohumeral
    - deltoid
    - Supraspinatus
- Scapulothoracic joint (upward rotation)
    - Serratus anterior
    - Upper trapezius

During abduction, the [subscapularis]({{< var ref-subscapularis.action >}}), [infraspinatus]({{< var ref-infraspinatus.action >}}), and [teres minor]({{< var ref-teres-minor.action >}}) draw the humeral the infero-medially during abduction @jonesProjectFoundations2025.

::: {.callout-note}
The [biceps brachii long head]({{< var ref-biceps-brachii-long-head.action >}}) is also involved in abduction and a rupture will result in ~20% decrease in abduction *strength* @jonesProjectFoundations2025.
:::

### Pure abduction

Pure abduction occurs in the frontal plane.

- Component III of lateral deltoid recruits first
- IV and V of posterior deltoid recruit immediately after @jonesProjectFoundations2025.
- Component II (anterior delt) recruits after the first 20-30&deg; @jonesProjectFoundations2025.

### Scapular plane abduction

Scapular plane exists between the sagittal and frontal planes.
30&deg; from the frontal plane @jonesProjectFoundations2025.

1. II (anterior deltoid) and III (lateral deltoid) are recruited first @jonesProjectFoundations2025.
1. IV and V (posterior deltoid) and I (Anterior deltoid) are recruited progressively later @jonesProjectFoundations2025.

### External rotation into abduction

1. II (anterior deltoid) contracts at the start

::: {.callout-note}
IV and V (Posterior deltoid) do not contract at all during this movement @jonesProjectFoundations2025.
:::

### IR to abduction

"recruitment order reverses" @jonesProjectFoundations2025.

# Axial Rotation

The "neutral" position in axial rotation is where the elbow is flexed to 90&deg; and the forearm is in the sagittal plane.

::: {.callout-note}
Another "neutral" position is at 30&deg; of internal rotation where the rotator muscles are at equilibrium @jonesProjectFoundations2025.
:::

# Stabilization

## Passive

The shoulder maintains its passive stability by using multiple structures arranged reciprocally so when one structure is lax, the other is tightened @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020. 
This allows the shoulder to have large degrees of freedom and ROM while limiting translation and rotation of the GHJ surfaces @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020. 

- GH ligaments 
- Capsule
    - Posterior capsule
- Glenoid labrum

## Active

- GHJ
    - RTC
- Shoulder elevation
    - Rhomboids
    - SA

# Bursae

According to Dutton @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020, the *synovium* of the *GH Joint Capsule* forms multiple bursae in shoulder complex @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020. 

- Subacromial bursae (Subdeltoid Bursae) @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020
    - Lies on the superior aspect of the joint @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020
    - Largest bursae of the shoulder complex @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020

"It also forms variously sized bursae, the largest of which, the subacromial or subdeltoid bursa, lies on the superior aspect of the joint (see later)." @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 

# Muscles

**Transverse muscles** (@tbl-shoulder-transverse-muscle-group-oian )press the humeral head against the glenoid cavity @jonesProjectFoundations2025.

The **longitudinal muscles** (@tbl-shoulder-longitudinal-muscle-group-oian) support the upper limb and prevent inferior disarticulation when carrying heavy objects @jonesProjectFoundations2025.
These muscles act to maintain or return the humeral head to the glenoid @jonesProjectFoundations2025.

# Biomechanics

## Arm Elevation

- SCAP UR: end range: post tilt and ER
    - End position: inf angle at midaxillary line
- GHJ: humeral elevation and lateral rotation, inf glide of humerus
- SCJ: elevation and post rotation and retraction


# Evaluation Inventory

## Prone

- Start at the superior angle of the scapula
- Palpate
    - [Upper trapezius]({{< var ref-upper-trapezius.path >}})
    - [Levator scapulae]({{< var ref-levator-scapulae.path >}})
    - [Rhomboid major]({{< var ref-rhomboid-major.path >}})
    - [Rhomboid minor]({{< var ref-rhomboid-minor >}})
    - [Middle trapezius]({{< var ref-middle-trapezius.path >}})
- Overall rib mobility
- Use medial/ulnar side of your carpals to depress and upwardly rotate the scapula to test scapulothoracic mobility
- Work on the rhomboids but bringing the scapula up and driving your fingers underneath the scapula

- Palpate
    - Supraspinatus (above spine of scap)
    - [Infraspinatus]({{< var ref-infraspinatus.palpation >}})
    - [Teres minor]({{< var ref-teres-minor.palpation >}})
    - [Teres major]({{< var ref-teres-major.palpation >}})
    - [Latissimus dorsi]({{< var ref-latissimus-dorsi.palpation >}})


## Supine

- [Anterior&rarr;Posterior GHJ glide to assess joint mobility, tendon gliding, and capsular mobility]({{< var ref-glenohumeral-joint.a-p-glide >}})
- [Superior&rarr;inferior GHJ glide assessment]({{< var ref-glenohumeral-joint.sup-inf-glide >}})
- [Subscapularis]({{< var ref-subscapularis.palpation >}})




# Treatment

## Prone


- GHJ P&rarr;A glide
- GHJ Sup&rarr;Inf Glide
- Upper trapezius
- [Levator scapulae]({{< var ref-levator-scapulae.release >}})
- [Rhomboid major]({{< var ref-rhomboid-major.release >}}) and [minor]({{< var ref-rhomboid-minor.release >}})
- middle trapezius
- Lower trapezius
- [Latissimus Dorsi]({{< var ref-latissimus-dorsi.release >}})
- Press between the ribs when working through the muscles in the back
- When working on [serratus anterior]({{< var ref-serratus-anterior.release >}}), apply your pressure *on* the ribs since the muscle belly attaches *on* the ribs @jonesProjectFoundations2025.
- RTC
    - [Supraspinatus]({{< var ref-supraspinatus.palpation >}})
    - [Infraspinatus]({{{< var ref-infraspinatus.palpation >}}})
    - [Teres minor]({{< var ref-teres-minor.palpation >}})
- [Teres major]({{< var ref-teres-major.release >}})


## Supine

- [Supraspinatus]({{< var ref-supraspinatus.release >}})
- [Upper trapezius]({{< var ref-upper-trapezius.release >}})
- Inferior clavicle
    - [Subclavius]({{< var ref-subclavius.release >}})
    - [Pectoralis major clavicular insertion]({{< var ref-pectoralis-major.release >}})
- Anterior GHJ
    - Tendon and capsule pin while posteriorly gliding the humeral head
- Superior GHJ
    - Inferior glide humeral head while bringing the arm into abduction
- [Subscapularis release]({{< var ref-subscapularis-release >}})

- [1st rib inferior mobilization with scalene release]({{< var ref-1st-rib-bone.release >}})
- [Scapula depression and superior glide with movement and Upper trapezius release]({{< var ref-scapulothoracic-joint.release >}})
- Median nerve tensioning
- Radial nerve tensioning
- Brachial plexus axillary release


# Special tests


::: {.callout-important}
Special tests are useful when attempting to diagnose the integrity of a certain structure, but should not distract you from taking an [inventory](#inventory) of all of the surrounding structures.
:::


- RTC
    - Subscap: Bear hug, Liftoff test
    - Champagne test
    - Hornblower's test
- Labral tear
    - Clunk test
- SLAP Tear
    - Speed's test (and bicipital tendinitis)
    - O'brien's test
- Anterior impingement
    - Hawkins-Kennedy test
- Posterior impingement
    - Posterior internal impingement test
- Posterior instability
    - Jerk test
- Inferior instability
    - Sulcus sign
- Anterior dislocation
    - Apprehension Test (Crank test)
    - Fulcrum test
- Posterior dislocation


# Diagnosis


## Considerations before using special tests:

Special tests for the shoulder have multiple issues.

:::{layout-ncol="3"}

### Poor Gold Standards

- Poor convergent validity: Special tests for the shoulder are based on MRI and ultrasounds, which are poor gold standards @salamhItTimePut2020.

### Poor Tissue Isolation (Specificity)

- In empty can for “ supra” 9 shoulder mm active, 
- During full can test 8 other mm were active

### Pain is unreliable

- Hyperalgesia: Areas with increased inflammatory markers can cause unrelated areas to be sensitive to certain positions.  For example the subacromial bursa has high concentrations of substance P and pro-inflammatory cytokines and is often aggravated by the Empty can test @salamhItTimePut2020.
- Allodynia: Pain is not directly related to tissue damage @salamhItTimePut2020.
:::

| Exercise | Movement | Scapula |
|-|-|-|
| T | 30&deg; above the transverse plane </br> scapular plane flexion | retraction |
| Y | Scapular flexion | Retraction + upward rotation + posterior tilt |
| I | Pure Flexion | Retraction + upward rotation + posterior tilt |
